elements.content: New bispyridyl ligands N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-diphthalic diimide (L ) and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-oxydiphthalic diimide (L ) were synthesized. Their coordination polymers [Cd(L 1 )1.5(NO3)2] n ·nCHCl3 (1) and [Cd(L 2 )2(NO3)2] n ·nEtOH (2) have either a 2D (6,3) brick-wall network with L 1 in both Z t - and U t -modes or a 1D chain of layered double-bridging Cd2 L 2 2 units with solely angular L 2 . The connection of the diimide moieties supplemented by the rich hydrogen bonding prevents interpenetration in 3D networks.
elements.clean_text: New bispyridyl ligands N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-diphthalic diimide (L    ) and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-oxydiphthalic diimide (L    ) were synthesized. Their coordination polymers [Cd(L  1  )1.5(NO3)2] n ⋅nCHCl3 (1) and [Cd(L  2  )2(NO3)2] n ⋅nEtOH (2) have either a 2D (6,3) brick-wall network with L  1   in both  Z   t - and  U   t -modes or a 1D chain of layered double-bridging Cd2 L  2   2 units with solely angular L  2  . The connection of the diimide moieties supplemented by the rich hydrogen bonding prevents interpenetration in 3D networks.

elements.content: Polymers [Cd(L 1 )1.5(NO3)2] n ·nCHCl3 (1) and [Cd(L 2 )2(NO3)2] n ·nEtOH (2) containing the two new ligands N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-diphthalic diimide (L 1 ) and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-oxydiphthalic diimide (L 2 ) have either a (6,3) brick-wall network with L 1 in both Z t - and U t -modes or a 1D chain of layered double-bridging Cd2 L 2 2 units with solely angular L 2 .
elements.clean_text: Polymers [Cd(L  1  )1.5(NO3)2] n ⋅nCHCl3 (1) and [Cd(L  2  )2(NO3)2] n ⋅nEtOH (2) containing the two new ligands N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-diphthalic diimide (L  1  ) and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-oxydiphthalic diimide (L  2  ) have either a (6,3) brick-wall network with L  1   in both  Z   t - and  U   t -modes or a 1D chain of layered double-bridging Cd2 L  2   2 units with solely angular L  2  .

elements.content: The formation of coordination polymers produced by N-donor bispyridyl derivated bridging ligands in combination with transition metal ions using a “building block” methodology has recently received much attention, not only because of the rich topological structures, but also for their encouraging properties for applications such as in gas absorption, photonic devices, and functional materials. Compared to the well-developed 4,4‘-N-donor bispyridyl bridging ligands, efforts on 3,3‘-N-donor analogues are relatively limited due to the difficulty encountered in isolation of crystalline complexes. During recent years, some discrete 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers generated from transition metal templates of the latter type of ligands containing rigid spacers have been reported, such as 3,3‘-bipy (3,3‘-bipyridine), 3,3‘-dpa (1,2-bis(3-pyridyl)ethyne), 3,3‘-pytz (3,6-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine), 3,3‘-pdabd (1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene), 3,3‘-pdahd (2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene), 3,3‘-bodz (2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole), and 3,3‘-btdz (2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-thiadiazole). These ligands are of particular interest owing to their potential to generate complexes of intriguing topology with the possibility of isomeric trans or cis conformation. Recently, a type of simple flexible 3,3‘-N-donor bipyridyl ligands Py2O and Py2S with angular spacers O or S has been reported in the formation of cyclindrical helices with Ag(I) salts. Conceivably, by replacing the O or S atom by other noncoordinating spacers, the adjusted and versatile flexibility of the ligands could lead to different coordination modes and sophisticated metal complexes can be constructed. To this end, the rational design and preparation of ligands of required geometry in the spacer seem extremely important to the construction of new polymeric architectures. We have begun the investigation on the syntheses of terminally substituted bis-pyridylmethyl diimide ligands in which the two pyridyl moieties are separated by diimide spacers, and the methylene groups allow the two pyridyl arms to rotate freely, thus providing flexibility to the ligands. Moreover, the diimide cores endow the ligands with rich hydrogen-bonding possibilities to build noninterpenetrating multidimensional networks and functional channels.

Compared to the well-developed 4,4‘-N-donor bispyridyl bridging ligands, efforts on 3,3‘-N-donor analogues are relatively limited due to the difficulty encountered in isolation of crystalline complexes. During recent years, some discrete 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers generated from transition metal templates of the latter type of ligands containing rigid spacers have been reported, such as 3,3‘-bipy (3,3‘-bipyridine), 3,3‘-dpa (1,2-bis(3-pyridyl)ethyne), 3,3‘-pytz (3,6-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine), 3,3‘-pdabd (1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene), 3,3‘-pdahd (2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene), 3,3‘-bodz (2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole), and 3,3‘-btdz (2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-thiadiazole). These ligands are of particular interest owing to their potential to generate complexes of intriguing topology with the possibility of isomeric trans or cis conformation. elements.content: In this communication, two new ligands N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-diphthalic diimide (L 1 , (3-PyPDM)2) and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-oxydiphthalic diimide (L 2 , (3-PyPDM)2O) (shown in Figures b and b in geometrical forms, respectively) with different angular geometries between the two phthalic diimide (PDM) moieties are reported:  straight chain versus bent bridging oxygen atom. Herein we report the structures of their Cd complexes [Cd(L 1 )1.5(NO3)2] n ·nCHCl3 (1) and [Cd(L 2 )2(NO3)2] n ·nEtOH (2), both containing nonpenetrating polymeric networks.
elements.clean_text: In this communication, two new ligands N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-diphthalic diimide (L  1  , (3-PyPDM)2) and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-oxydiphthalic diimide (L  2  , (3-PyPDM)2O) (shown in Figures b and b in geometrical forms, respectively) with different angular geometries between the two phthalic diimide (PDM) moieties are reported: straight chain versus bent bridging oxygen atom. Herein we report the structures of their Cd complexes [Cd(L  1  )1.5(NO3)2] n ⋅nCHCl3 (1) and [Cd(L  2  )2(NO3)2] n ⋅nEtOH (2), both containing nonpenetrating polymeric networks.

elements.content: Ligands L 1 and L 2 were synthesized18 by the reaction of 3,3‘-aminomethyl-pyridine with diphthalic dianhydride and 4,4‘-oxydiphthalic dianhydride, respectively, in DMF with reflux. Complexes 1 and 2 were obtained19 by layering the solution of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O above the solution of ligand. Colorless crystals suitable for single-crystal analyses were obtained in ca. 60% yield after standing the solutions for several days at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Ligands L  1   and L  2   were synthesized18 by the reaction of 3,3‘-aminomethyl-pyridine with diphthalic dianhydride and 4,4‘-oxydiphthalic dianhydride, respectively, in DMF with reflux. Complexes 1 and 2 were obtained19 by layering the solution of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O above the solution of ligand. Colorless crystals suitable for single-crystal analyses were obtained in ca. 60% yield after standing the solutions for several days at room temperature.

elements.content: The IR spectra of 1 and 2 showed characteristic absorption bands for coordinated NO3 -. The absorptions for the carboxyl groups of diimides appear at 1770, 1711 cm-1 for 1 and 1771, 1708 cm-1 for 2, all slightly blue shifted as compared to those in the free ligands (1765, 1708 cm-1 for L 1 , and 1766, 1707 cm-1 for L 2 ) due to distinct hydrogen-bonding formation.
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra of 1 and 2 showed characteristic absorption bands for coordinated NO3 -. The absorptions for the carboxyl groups of diimides appear at 1770, 1711 cm-1 for 1 and 1771, 1708 cm-1 for 2, all slightly blue shifted as compared to those in the free ligands (1765, 1708 cm-1 for L  1  , and 1766, 1707 cm-1 for L  2  ) due to distinct hydrogen-bonding formation.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal analyses20 showed that complex 1 from ligand L 1 with a C−C single bond as a rigid connector (spacer) of the two PDM moieties contains a 2D polymeric network for the neutral polymer [Cd(L 1 )1.5(NO3)2] n , with a chloroform solvate to each Cd ion. The Cd(II) center lies in a hepta-coordinate environment of N3O4 where the 3N atoms are from the 3-pyridyl groups of three individual L 1 and 4O from two bidentately coordinated NO3 - (Figure a). What is unusual is the fact that the rigidity of the straight chain connector affords both the Z t - and U t -modes (Figure b) of L 1 possible, thus affording two of the three L 1 in the U t -mode (Cd···Cd distance ca. 19.1 Å) and the third in the Z t -mode (Cd···Cd ca. 20.5 Å), forming a distorted T-shape module for the CdL 1 3 moiety as shown in Figure a. The T-shaped species1c was first recognized in the complexes of 4,4‘-bispyridyl derivatives by Fujita. In the solid state, complex 1 adopts an infinite 2D noninterpenetrating (6,3) brick-wall architecture (Figure ) composed of chair form “cyclohexyl” Cd6 L 1 6 units, and each unit creates a metallomacrocyclic ring structure with a size estimated by Cd-to-Cd distances of 20.5 Å × (2 × 19.1) Å. Such conformational combination of the Z t - and U t -modes of ligands has not been reported before, although the single trans or cis conformation of the low-symmetry rigid 3,3‘-bipyridyl ligands3-9 or the single Z - or U -mode of symmetrical flexible 4,4‘-bipyridyl ligands1 in their metal complexes has been documented. Interpenetration of the network with 3,3‘-bipyridyl ligand was only observed in the few examples7 found for complexes with rigid ligands. It is noteworthy that various C−H···O hydrogen bonds (listed in Table 1S, Supporting Information), involving oxygen atoms from both the PDMs and nitrate groups formed among the 2D networks leading to a noninterpenetrating 3D framework, while the solvate CHCl3 molecules are located between the 2D layers with weak hydrogen-bonding interactions (also seen in Table 1S, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: X-ray single-crystal analyses20 showed that complex 1 from ligand L  1   with a C-C single bond as a rigid connector (spacer) of the two PDM moieties contains a 2D polymeric network for the neutral polymer [Cd(L  1  )1.5(NO3)2] n , with a chloroform solvate to each Cd ion. The Cd(II) center lies in a hepta-coordinate environment of N3O4 where the 3N atoms are from the 3-pyridyl groups of three individual L  1   and 4O from two bidentately coordinated NO3 - (Figure a). What is unusual is the fact that the rigidity of the straight chain connector affords both the  Z   t - and  U   t -modes (Figure b) of L  1   possible, thus affording two of the three L  1   in the  U   t -mode (Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance ca. 19.1 Å) and the third in the  Z   t -mode (Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd ca. 20.5 Å), forming a distorted T-shape module for the CdL  1   3 moiety as shown in Figure a. The T-shaped species1c was first recognized in the complexes of 4,4‘-bispyridyl derivatives by Fujita. In the solid state, complex 1 adopts an infinite 2D noninterpenetrating (6,3) brick-wall architecture (Figure ) composed of chair form "cyclohexyl" Cd6 L  1   6 units, and each unit creates a metallomacrocyclic ring structure with a size estimated by Cd-to-Cd distances of 20.5 Å × (2 × 19.1) Å. Such conformational combination of the  Z   t - and  U   t -modes of ligands has not been reported before, although the single trans or cis conformation of the low-symmetry rigid 3,3‘-bipyridyl ligands3-9 or the single  Z - or  U -mode of symmetrical flexible 4,4‘-bipyridyl ligands1 in their metal complexes has been documented. Interpenetration of the network with  3,3‘-bipyridyl ligand was only observed in the few examples7 found for complexes with rigid ligands. It is noteworthy that various C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (listed in Table 1S, Supporting Information), involving oxygen atoms from both the PDMs and nitrate groups formed among the 2D networks leading to a noninterpenetrating 3D framework, while the solvate CHCl3 molecules are located between the 2D layers with weak hydrogen-bonding interactions (also seen in Table 1S, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Structure of complex1. (a) View of an asymmetric unit in 30% probability ellipsoids. The solvate molecule and the hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. (b) Stick representation of the Z t - and U t -mode of the coordinated L 1 :  Z for anti-orientation of the pyridyl rings, U for syn orientation of the pyridyl rings, t for trans of the N atoms in 3-pyridyl substituents.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of complex1. (a) View of an asymmetric unit in 30% probability ellipsoids. The solvate molecule and the hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. (b) Stick representation of the  Z   t  - and  U   t -mode of the coordinated L  1  :  Z  for anti-orientation of the pyridyl rings,  U  for syn orientation of the pyridyl rings, t for trans of the N atoms in 3-pyridyl substituents.

elements.content: Schematic representation of the 2D brick-wall network in1 showing the chair-form “cyclohexyl” macrometallacyclic Cd6 L 1 6 rings (Cd(II) green ball; U t -mode L 1 red stick; Z t -mode L 1 blue stick).
elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic representation of the 2D brick-wall network in1 showing the chair-form "cyclohexyl" macrometallacyclic Cd6 L  1   6 rings (Cd(II) green ball;  U   t -mode L  1   red stick;  Z   t -mode L  1   blue stick).

elements.content: The change of the connector from a single C−C bond to an oxygen bridge leads to a significant change in the geometry between the two PDM moieties. Such an increase on the flexibility of L 2 (dihedral angle of the two PDM moieties is 119°) leads to the coordination environmental change of Cd(II) ions in 2, which now adopt distorted octahedral geometry of N4O2 defined by four pyridyl nitrogen donors from four angular L 2 and two oxygen atoms from two monodentately coordinated NO3 - anions (Figure a). Two L 2 and two Cd(II) ions form a 40-membered metallomacrocyclic ring with Cd···Cd distances of ca. 9.49 Å. Overlapping of the Cd2 L 2 2 rings with Cd(II) as the nodes forms an infinite nonpenetrating loop-chain (Figure ). Compared to the double-bridged chain formed from flexible 4,4‘-bispyridyl ligands and a M(NO3)2 system, no aromatic molecule templates here lead to the alternative tetrakis-pyridyl framework. It is noteworthy that in the 3D framework (Figure S, Supporting Information) of 2 constructed by C−H···O hydrogen bonds (as listed in Table 1S, Supporting Information) among the 1D loop chains, channels as shown in Figure S (Supporting Information) are formed and EtOH molecules are enclathrated within. The enclathration is not the result of hetero recognition, but intermolecular C−H···O hydrogen bonds of guest molecules during the self-recognition.
elements.clean_text: The change of the connector from a single C-C bond to an oxygen bridge leads to a significant change in the geometry between the two PDM moieties. Such an increase on the flexibility of L  2   (dihedral angle of the two PDM moieties is 119°) leads to the coordination environmental change of Cd(II) ions in 2, which now adopt distorted octahedral geometry of N4O2 defined by four pyridyl nitrogen donors from four angular L  2   and two oxygen atoms from two monodentately coordinated NO3 - anions (Figure a). Two L  2   and two Cd(II) ions form a 40-membered metallomacrocyclic ring with Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances of ca. 9.49 Å. Overlapping of the Cd2 L  2   2 rings with Cd(II) as the nodes forms an infinite nonpenetrating loop-chain (Figure ). Compared to the double-bridged chain formed from flexible 4,4‘-bispyridyl ligands and a M(NO3)2 system, no aromatic molecule templates here lead to the alternative tetrakis-pyridyl framework. It is noteworthy that in the 3D framework (Figure S, Supporting Information) of 2 constructed by C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (as listed in Table 1S, Supporting Information) among the 1D loop chains, channels as shown in Figure S (Supporting Information) are formed and EtOH molecules are enclathrated within. The enclathration is not the result of hetero recognition, but intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds of guest molecules during the self-recognition.

elements.content: View of the 1D molecular loop chain in2 showing the overlapping units Cd2 L 2 2, pink color shows one complete unit and green ball:  Cd; red ball:  O; blue ball:  N. The nitrate groups were omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In conclusion, terminally substituted pyridylmethyl ligands containing two PDM moeities can be rationally designed by varying the connector in between, whose transition metal complexes showed rich topological varieties. Hydrogen bondings prevent penetration, thus forming channels or large cavities which should be significant in the application of these polymers as functional materials. The study of other 3,3‘-N-donor bipyridyl ligands with spacers of varying flexibility and angularity and their metal complexation behavior will be reported in due course.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, terminally substituted pyridylmethyl ligands containing two PDM moeities can be rationally designed by varying the connector in between, whose transition metal complexes showed rich topological varieties. Hydrogen bondings prevent penetration, thus forming channels or large cavities which should be significant in the application of these polymers as functional materials. The study of other 3,3‘-N-donor bipyridyl ligands with spacers of varying flexibility and angularity and their metal complexation behavior will be reported in due course.

elements.content: Crystallographic information files; hydrogen bond distances and angles for complexes 1 and 2 (Table S1); 2D brick-wall network in 1 showing the metallocyclic M6[(3-PyPDM)2]6 ring (Figure S1); 3D framework in 2 formed via intermolecular CHO hydrogen bond (Figure S2). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Nonpenetrating Architectures of Cd(II) Complexes Constructed by
Bispyridyl-Substituted Diphthalic Diimide Ligands of Varied
Geometry
